Insight into the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein over Ce-accelerated Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalyst Qinghui Li Investigation Methodology Software Writing – original draft Formal analysis a b Huahua Zhao Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Supervision a ⁎ Jian Yang Data curation a Jun Zhao Formal analysis a Liang Yan Investigation a Huanling Song Supervision Formal analysis a Lingjun Chou Supervision Conceptualization a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China aState Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Understanding the mechanism of multi-component metal oxide catalyst for the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein has long been challenging for its complexity. Herein, the key role of Ce on the Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalysts for accelerating the selectivity of methacrolein was revealed. It was suggested that the Ce addition could replace the Bi3+ and then generate defects which changed the transformation of electron and the migration mobility of ions: Ⅰ. the production of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox couples regulated the catalytic redox ability; and Ⅱ. the interaction effect between Ce and Co enhanced the storage capacity and mobility of oxygen which could benefit the adsorption and activation ability for isobutene molecules. Interestingly, it was found that adding appropriate amount of Ce adjusted the molar ratio of the catalytically active lattice oxygen and defect oxygen species. Therefore, proper amount of Ce addition to the catalyst significantly accelerated the methacrolein selectivity from 47.9% to 70.6%. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Multi-component metal oxide catalyst Oxygen species Selective oxidation Isobutene Methacrolein 1 Introduction The upgrade of light olefins widely produced from naphtha catalytic cracking, light alkane dehydrogenation and coal utilization, is a crucial challenge and opportunity for the petrochemical industry and modern coal chemical industry. Directional conversion of light olefins into valued-added oxygen-containing compounds is currently recognized as an effective way to consume excess olefins and improve the competitiveness of light olefins industry [1–3]. As an important portion of light olefins, isobutene (IB) is generally applied as raw material to prepare butyl rubber, poly-isobutene and methyl methacrylate (MMA), which is a very important organic chemical raw material. During the production process of MMA, the selective oxidation of IB to methacrolein (MAL) is the first step, which is also the necessary and the most critical step in two-step or three-step IB oxidation strategy. Considering that IB containing two active -CH3 and the more active product - MAL are prone to deep oxidation under the reaction conditions, it is thus very important to construct a catalyst with both high activity and selectivity. Reducible multi-component metal oxides, particularly, molybdenum-bismuth-based metal oxides that can be represented as Mo-Bi-MⅢ-MⅡ-MⅠ-X-O, have been utilized for the selective oxidation of IB to MAL in industrial manufacture in recent years [4–10]. Additional elements play essential roles for performing high activity, excellent selectivity, and good stability of catalysts. MⅢ is usually Fe3+, Ce3+ and Cr3+, etc. MⅡ contains Ni2+, Co2+ and Mg2+, etc. MⅠ additives contain K +, Na+, Cs+ and so on. Other valence elements including V5+, Sn4+ and Nb5+ were also commonly introduced. Extensive studies have investigated the reaction mechanism [11], including the active sites [12], the nature of reaction intermediate [13] and the role of additional elements [14–20]. Indeed, the complexity of the Mo-Bi-based multi-component metal oxide catalyst makes it difficult to probe the active phase and the role of each component in this system. Currently, the rare earth element Ce is usually utilized as the redox additive to produce phase-synergistic effect and affect the transfer of lattice oxygen, thus improving the performance of the catalyst. For example, Ce doping could significantly increase the surface oxygen defects and release rate of lattice oxygen, meanwhile, facilitate O2 adsorption [21–23]. As a representative example of producing interaction with other elements, Ce could form interaction with Fe which has been supported be beneficial for the enhancement of oxygen storage and release ability [24,25]. Another noteworthy example is the proper doping of Ce precisely tuned the Co3+/Co2+ ratio and induce surface oxygen defects in Ce-Co3O4 [26]; In Ce-Mo oxide, the promotional effect of oxygen spillover from CeO2 to Ce2(MoO4)3 to realize the high reactivity of lattice oxygen ions [27]. However, it is a great challenge to confirm the exact role of Ce in the structure and establish a unified theoretical system over the multi-component metal oxide catalysts. In this work, Ce doped on the featured Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalysts for selective oxidation of IB to MAL was investigated in detail. The effect of Ce addition on the surface and bulk composition, structure, redox and basic properties of the catalysts was analyzed in depth based on a series of characterizations involving X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). In particular, the role of different oxygen species in selective oxidation of IB was proposed based on the catalytic performance, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). Moreover, the promotion of Ce over IB adsorption and activation was found according to IB-temperature programmed desorption (i-C4-TPD) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) over the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The series of Ce-accelerated catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method. Firstly, (NH4)6MoO24·4H2O was dissolved in deionized water and stirred at 50 ℃ to obtain solution A. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and KNO3 were dissolved in 5 M nitric acid and stirred to obtain solution B at room temperature. Solution B was then added dropwise to solution A at 50 ℃ with stirring to obtain slurry. Ammonia water (5%) was utilized to regulate pH of the mixture to 5 then which was rotary evaporated at 70 ℃ to get a paste, followed by being dried in air at 120 ℃ and calcined at 450 ℃ for 3 h to prepare multi-component metal oxides with stoichiometric molar ratio of 12:1.5:1.5:5:x:5:0.5 for Mo: Bi: Fe: Co: Ce: K. Finally, the catalysts were crushed into particles between 20 and 40 mesh and denoted as Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O which the value of x was from 0 to 1.2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) technology was employed to characterize the phase of catalysts through Smartlab-SE Multipurpose diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). LabRam HR800 Jobin-Yvon spectrometer was utilized to obtain Raman spectrum. Each element of the catalyst samples was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) through Thermon ESCALAB 250xi spectrometer using Al Kα (hν = 1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source. The binding energies were corrected by the C 1 s reference peak at 284.8 eV. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured through Autosorb-iQ. H2-TPR, O2-TPD, i-C4-TPD and CO2-TPD measurements were performed on using a ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD analyzer, respectively. For H2-TPR, the catalysts (0.05 g) were pretreated at 200 ℃ in He flow (35 ml·min−1) for 60 min before analysis. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was reduced in a 10% H2/Ar stream (35 ml·min−1). H2 consumption of the catalysts was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and collected the signal from room temperature to 1000 ℃ at a rate of 20 ℃∙min−1. For O2-TPD, i-C4-TPD and CO2-TPD, the catalysts (0.2 g) were pretreated at 200 ℃ in He flow (35 ml·min−1) for 60 min before analysis. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was exposed in O2, C4H8 or CO2 stream (35 ml·min−1) and then heating to 1000 ℃ at a rate of 20 ℃·min−1 in He flow. The gas consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Mass spectroscopy (MS, LC-D200M) was employed to collect the signals of O2, CO, CO2 and C4H8 with the m/z of 32, 28, 44 and 56, respectively. X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) was carried out utilizing Magix PW2403 to analyze the relative content of each element in the catalysts. EPR characterization was utilized to explore the existence of oxygen vacancies by Bruker A300. In-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of IB adsorption and reaction on the catalyst surface (In situ IB-FTIR) was performed by Nicolet Nexus 870. The catalyst was pretreated at 450 ℃ in N2 flow (30 ml·min−1) for 60 min before analysis, then cooled to 400 ℃ and exposed to IB (30 ml·min−1) for some time until the spectrum was not changed. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalysts were performed in the oxidation of IB at ambient-pressure in a fixed-bed reactor. The catalyst bed was constituted by 1 mL catalyst diluted with 1 mL quartz sand. The reaction temperature was 400 ℃, with C4H8: air (v:v) = 4: 96 at a total flow of 9200 h−1. Using CH4 as internal standard gas, product analysis was performed by two on-line gas chromatographs operating three columns: a TDX-01 column and Al2O3 column for the separation of C3H8, C3H6, C2H4, CH4, CO, CO2, etc.; a DB-5 column for the separation of acetaldehyde, acrolein, acetone, MAL, maleic anhydride and other products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic performance of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O The major products of the IB oxidation over Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts were MAL, methacrylic acid and carbon oxides (CO and CO2). However, small amounts of acetic acid, maleic anhydride, acetone, benzoic acid and hydrocarbons (ethane, ethylene, propylene and so on) were also detectable. The results of IB oxidation over the series of catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 a and Table S1. The Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst performed IB conversion of 99.0% with much lower MAL selectivity of 47.9%. After Ce doping, the IB conversion was basically maintained, notably, the selectivity of MAL increased with the increment of Ce content. The MAL selectivity reached as high as 70.6% toward Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O, increased by 22.7% than that of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O, while preventing overoxidation to COx by-products at the lowest selectivity of 12.4%. With the further addition of Ce (x > 0.2), MAL selectivity remarkably decreased and the COx selectivity increased simultaneously. These results suggested that moderate doping of Ce to the catalysts promoted the reaction performance for MAL selectivity. Moreover, the production rate of MAL (rMAL) over the catalysts was calculated [28,29]. As described in Fig. 1b and Table 1 , the variation of rMAL value was consistent with the catalytic performance that 0.2Ce addition was the best doping content. This meant that the Ce-doping could elevate the utilization of Mo and Bi active sites. 3.2 The bulk composition and structure of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts The bulk composition of the catalysts was firstly detected by XRF characterization, as shown in Table 2 . It was observed that the actual molar ratio of all the elements was predominately close to the corresponding theoretical ratio of all the elements in the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts. In order to explore the phase structure of the multi-component catalysts, XRD characterizations were carried out as described in Fig. 2 a. All the samples possessed typical peaks assigned to β-CoMoO4 (JCPDS: 21–0868), α-Bi2Mo3O12 (JCPDS: 23–1033), MoO3 (JCPDS: 35–0609), and γ-Bi2MoO6 (JCPDS: 21–0102), respectively. The Ce-doped catalysts exhibited the similar phase structure compared with the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst. However, it was carefully observed that the intensity of the peak appeared at 2θ = 28.4° (θγ), belonging to the strongest peak of γ-Bi2MoO6 phase weakened compared with that of the peak located at 2θ = 27.9° (θα) which was assigned to the strongest peak of α-Bi2Mo3O12 when Ce was doped, as clearly shown in Table S2. This phenomenon indicated that Ce3+ probably substituted for part of Bi3+ in γ-Bi2MoO6 phase to form well-distributed Ce2MoO6, which was might due to that Ce3+ in the catalyst could partially replace Bi3+ (the ionic radius of Ce3+ (1.01 × 10−12 m) is close to that of Bi3+ (1.03 × 10−12 m)) [30]. Still, no Ce-based phase was observed. This substitution could form defect on the catalyst which changed the migration ability of ions. According to previous studies, CeMoOx could form synergistic effect with γ-Bi2MoO6 phase [16] and enhance the oxygen spillover [24]. Combined with the catalytic performance, the presence of less γ-Bi2MoO6 phase in the Ce-doped catalysts might improve MAL selectivity because pure γ-Bi2MoO6 phase exhibits a high selectivity toward CO and CO2 according to previous studies [31,32]. As is well known, the multicomponent metal oxide catalyst generally possesses small specific surface area [33]. Therefore, N2-physisorption isotherms were further detected, and the pore size distribution of the series of catalysts were provided out, as presented in Table 2 and Fig. S1. Expectedly, the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst exhibited the small BET specific surface area of 13.2 m2·g−1, pore volume of 0.15 cm3·g−1 and pore diameter of 13.0 nm. However, adding Ce slightly accelerated the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. The increase of specific surface area meant that reaction gas had greater chance to contact with the catalysts and rich active surface sites in the catalysts [21,34,35]. 3.3 The surface composition and structure of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts To probe the effect of Ce doping on the surface composition of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts, XPS spectra was performed and the molar ratio of elements as shown in Table 2. It was not difficult to notice that the surface contents of Fe, K and Ce element were slightly higher, while the surface content of Co element was much lower than the corresponding bulk content in the series catalysts, demonstrating the nonuniformity of the elements on the catalyst bulk and surface. This phenomenon was consistent with the result of XRD that Ce addition could enhance the formation of defects and then benefited the migration of elements. The Ce 3d XPS spectra was further fitted and quantified, as shown in Table 3 and Fig. S2. Based on the previous literatures, the Ce 3d XPS spectra could be de-convoluted into ten distinct peaks. The binding energy (BE) located at 880.24 eV, 885.29 eV, 898.27 eV and 903.46 eV were assigned to Ce3+, the BE at 882.26 eV, 888.39 eV, 897.76 eV, 900.50 eV, 907.86 eV and 916.01 eV were attributed to Ce4+, respectively [36]. The addition of Ce could promote the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface which coupled with the generation of oxygen vacancies and resulted from the relative molar amount of Ce3+/Ce3++Ce4+ were gradually increased from 0.35 (x = 0.05) to 0.53 (x = 1.2). The formation and valence change of the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple could help to motivate lattice oxygen, enhance oxygen mobility and accelerate the production of oxygen vacancies [23,37,38]. The Co 2p XPS spectra can be de-convoluted into six distinct peaks, as shown in Table 3 and Fig. S2. The BE at 779.92 eV and 795.94 eV, belonging to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, were assigned to Co3+, the BE at 782.78 eV, 786.57 eV, 797.81 eV and 802.54 eV, owing to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 as well as the characteristic satellite peaks, were assigned to Co2+ [26], respectively. The addition of Ce decreased the surface relative molar amount of Co3+/Co2++Co3+ from 0.55 to 0.51, thus promoting the generation of surface Co2+/Co3+redox couple, which could weaken the strength of the CoO bond, and boost the mobility of active oxygen species [17,39]. Ce3+/Ce4+and Co2+/Co3+redox couples could promote the transition of charge carriers in the bulk of catalyst. In addition, different ionic radius and valences of different elements will lead to lattice distortion, increase oxygen vacancies due to their interaction with adjacent transition metal elements [26,40,41]. In order to explore the influence of Ce on oxygen species of the catalyst surface, therefore, we also quantified O 1 s XPS as shown in Table 3 and Fig. S2. The BE located at 531.0 eV, 530.6 eV and 532.7 eV were assigned to O atoms next to a defect (‘Odefect’), lattice oxygen (‘Olattice’) and surface hydroxyls (‘OH’) [26], respectively. The relative ratio of Olattice/Odefect was changed, meaning that Ce could enhance the component variation of active surface oxygen species. Raman spectra of the series catalysts were in succession performed to characterize the surface phase structure, as shown in Fig. 2b. The Raman shifts of all the samples were similar, demonstrating that the phase structure of the catalysts was basically unchanged after Ce doping. Three regions of 1000–660, 470–280, and 250–100 cm−1 were attributed to Mo-O stretching, Mo=O bending, and Mo-O-Mo deformation modes [42]. Specifically, the Raman shift at 113, 124, 151, 194, 214, 239, 286, 334, 376, 470, 663, 817and 991 cm−1 were assigned to α-MoO3 phase [43]. In addition, the peaks at 663 and 937 cm−1 could be taken as α-Bi2Mo3O12. Meantime, the shift at 817 cm−1 was also assigned to the presence of γ-Bi2MoO6 phase, and 937 cm−1 could also be attributed to CoMoO4 [44,45]. As expected, the results of Raman spectra, which clearly showed the catalytic phase, were consistent with that of XRD characterizations. 3.4 The redox properties of the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts The variation of redox couples and the generation of defects is closely related to the redox properties. The catalysts with different Ce contents were characterized by H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 3 a. In the profile of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst, the peak appearing at 560–630 ℃ corresponded to the reduction from Mo6+ to Mo4+ [46], the peak at 630–745 ℃ was assigned to the reduction from Bi3+ to Bi0 [47], and the broad peak appearing at 745–930 ℃ was taken to the further reduction from Mo4+ to Mo0 [48]. It was evidently observed that the reduction temperature of Mo6+ species over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst remained basically unchanged at 609–612 ℃ after Ce addition, with slightly decreasing to 604 ℃ only over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O catalyst, which meant that proper doping-amount of Ce might be more conducive to the Mo6+ reduction and promote the spillover of active oxygen species [25,27]. However, with the decrease in the relative amount of γ-Bi2MoO6 after Ce doping based on the XRD results, the reduction peak positions of Bi3+ species were all shifted from 687 ℃ over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst to much higher temperature over the Ce-doping catalysts, indicating that the interaction between Bi species and other component was stronger. Whereas, the reduction peak intensities of Mo6+ and Bi3+ species firstly grew strong and then gradually grew weakened with the increasing amount of Ce, meaning that the contents of two species on the catalyst surface were both increased firstly and then showed decreasing trends, which was consistent with the trends of the molar ratio about Mo and Bi at the catalyst surface detected by XPS as shown in Table 2 and Table S3. Furthermore, CO2 was interestingly found to be reduced into CO on the catalyst surface, as shown in Fig. 3b, the CO signal (m/z = 28) was detected at different temperatures during CO2-TPD process. There were clearly three peaks located at 370–430, 430–500 and 500–550 ℃, implying there presented three types of active reduction sites over the catalysts. After adding Ce, the amount of the reduction sites firstly increased and then decreased, while reaching the maximum when x = 0.2 as shown in Table S3, indicating that the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O catalyst possessed the stronger reduction ability. Moreover, the latter peak at 430–550 ℃ became the unique one with the peak area decreasing gradually when x > 0.4, suggesting the reduction capacity of the catalyst was restrained. Consequently, combining H2-TPR and CO2-TPD-CO results, Ce addition could change the redox properties of catalysts which benefited oxygen spillover. O2-TPD characterizations were utilized to probe the oxygen species over the catalysts, as described in Fig. 4 and Table 3. It is generally accepted that there are three types of oxygen species. Based on the previously reported literatures, the first was physically adsorbed oxygen desorbed below 200 ℃ which was barely detected. And then, surface active oxygen species were usually desorbed at 200–600 ℃ [49,50]. Moreover, it was clearly observed that there were two desorption peaks at 400–600 ℃. The one which denoted as Peak 1, located at lower temperature at 430–530 ℃, was assumed to be the desorption of surface Odefect species. The one which labeled as Peak 2, situated at higher temperature of 530–600 ℃, belonged to the surface Olattice species [51–54]. The last desorption peak above 600 ℃ denoted as Peak 3, was assigned to the lattice oxygen in bulk of the catalyst. To further confirm the type of oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst. The EPR spectra was utilized to confirm the existence of oxygen vacancies as shown in Fig. S3. Symmetric peaks with g-value around 2.004 (2.003) were observed on Ce doped and without Ce doped catalysts, which were attributed to surface oxygen vacancies [55]. In addition, it is known that the gas phase O2 could occupy the vacancies to form Odefect species at the catalyst surface, therefore, O2-TPD process of the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce1.2K0.5O catalyst without the step of O2 adsorption was further carried out as shown in Fig. 4b. Obviously, the peak area of Olattice species was changeless, while the peak area of Odefect species decreased remarkably without O2 adsorption which confirmed that Peak 1was assigned to Odefect species. In detailed, the peak position and area were detected due to the increasement of defects had great influence on the generation and migration ability of Olattice species and of Odefect species. For Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst, the desorption temperatures of surface Odefect and Olattice were 536 ℃ and 547 ℃, respectively. However, the two desorption temperatures shifted to lower temperatures with the increasing Ce addition, which indicated that Ce could greatly enhance the migration ability of active surface oxygen species of the catalysts. Furthermore, it was clearly observed that the content of both surface oxygen species ascended significantly, demonstrating the adsorption capacity of oxygen species in Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O was much stronger than that of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O. Moreover, the molar ratio of Olattice to Odefect species on the catalyst surface firstly increased and then gradually decreased with the increment of Ce doping as shown in Table 4 . In order to explore the main reason for the increased surface oxygen storage of the Ce doped catalysts, we performed O2-TPD characterizations for Mo12Bi1.5Ce0.4K0.5O, Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Ce0.4K0.5O and Mo12Bi1.5Co5Ce0.4K0.5O catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4a, there were very weak signals at 400–600 °C on the profile of Mo12Bi1.5Ce0.4K0.5O and Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Ce0.4K0.5O catalysts, indicating that the only Ce addition amount and the interaction of Fe and Ce were non-dominant factors for the generation of Odefect species on the catalyst surface. However, as expected, the Mo12Bi1.5Co5Ce0.4K0.5O catalysts appeared very obvious signal at 400–600 °C, proving that the phase-synergistic interaction of Co and Ce primarily benefited the generation of active oxygen species on the catalyst surface. It is generally assumed that the active site of IB oxidation to MAL on the Mo-Bi based multi-component metal oxide is the lattice oxygen species on the catalyst surface [11,13]. To check whether the surface Olattice species was responsible for the production of MAL in the reaction, we plotted the production rate of MAL and COx on Mo and Bi sites (rMAL−Mo, rMAL-Bi, rCOx−Mo and rCOx-Bi) versus the amount of surface Olattice species over the series catalysts, as analyzed in Fig. 5 . Notably, the rMAL reached the maximum when the content of surface Olattice species was 7.30 × 10−3 mmol·g−1, demonstrating the surface Olattice species on the catalysts was the very important active site for MAL production during reaction. Meantime, this phenomenon implied that MAL generation was not solely dependent on surface Olattice species. The rMAL and rCOx versus the content of surface Odefect species over the series catalysts was also plotted as shown in Fig. 5b. Surprisingly, the rMAL in Mo and Bi sites first increased then decreased with the increasing content of surface Odefect species and reached the maximum when the content of surface Odefect species was 0.95 × 10−3 mmol·g−1. This indicated that the surface Odefect species was one of the active sites for the reaction of IB selective oxidation to MAL. In addition, the increasing or decreasing rate of the production rate (described as k0 value) on Mo or Bi sites in the upward and downward trend were calculated when the content of Odefect species were changed. It was clearly seen that Bi site had bigger k value (k0 = 1.655 and 0.459) in upward trend and had smaller k value (k0 = −0.370 and −0.842) in downward trend compared with Mo site, confirming that the Ce addition had greater impact on the Odefect around the Bi site than the Mo sites. This phenomenon indicated that Ce-doping exerted significant influence on the chemical environment around Bi site, which well consistent with the result of XRD. Moreover, rMAL reached optimal value but rCOx reached minimum value at the molar ratio of surface Olattice and Odefect species of 7.7 on Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O. This phenomenon implied that the catalytic activity was not only related to the content of oxygen species, but also depended on the molar ratio of Odefect to Olattice on the surface of the catalyst. Consequently, adding Ce could produce the phase-synergistic interaction and defects, accelerate the generation of surface oxygen species, and regulate the proportion of surface Olattice and Odefect species over the catalyst, thus inhibiting COx production and promoting the production of MAL. 3.5 The basicity of the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts It is widely recognized that acidic sites could cause overoxidation for IB selective oxidation [19]. On the basis of the studies about the acceleration effect of Ce for IB selective oxidation to MAL, the Ce addition was expected to bring more basic sites to the catalyst [56,57]. To test this speculation, CO2 signals were detected by TCD and the corresponding CO2-TPD profiles of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 6 and Table S3. There were three peaks at different temperatures. The peak appearing at lower than 400, 400–650 ℃ and higher than 650 ℃ were attributed to weak, medium-strong and strong basic sites, respectively. Obviously, there were mainly medium-strong basic sites over the catalyst system. Further analysis of the peak area in Table S3, it was found that Ce addition could increase the amount of both the weak and medium-strong basic sites. As is known, MAL molecule possesses electron-rich C=C and C=O double bonds, thus presenting weak basicity. Ce addition could enhance the weak and medium-strong basicity of the catalysts, which facilitates the desorption of MAL product which maybe an important factor leading to the increase of the MAL selectivity. 3.6 Promoting the adsorption and activation of IB on the catalyst surface i-C4-TPD was firstly performed and tried to identify the effect of Ce addition on the adsorption properties of IB over the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7 . It could be clearly that there were two broad desorption peaks at 100–300 and 300–600 ℃ over all the catalysts in Fig. 7a, respectively. After further analysis about data from MS detector (probably due to the larger m/z value, MAL and other productions were undetectable in MS), unexpectedly, both the two peaks belonged to the desorption of CO and CO2 over the catalysts as shown in Fig. 7c,d and Table S4. And no desorption of IB was detected over Ce-doping catalysts which shown in Fig. 7b, indicating that IB had already reacted with the active oxygen species on the catalyst before desorption under the detective conditions. Therefore, in-situ FTIR characterizations of IB adsorption were further performed on the catalyst. Fig. 8 shows the in-situ IB-FTIR spectra about the IB adsorption and reaction on the two catalysts Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O and Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O without oxygen at 400 ℃. The peak at 1200–1500 cm−1 corresponded to the bending vibration of CH3 and deformation vibration of CH2. The peak at 1573 cm−1 was assigned to asymmetric stretching vibration of COO−. The peak at 1638 cm−1 corresponded to the vibration of OH in H2O and the peak at 1655 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of C=C. The band at 1700–1900 cm−1 was assigned to the typical peak of aldehyde (it might be MAL). The peak appeared at 2362 and 2339 cm−1 which assigned to COx. And the peaks at 2800–3000 cm−1 corresponded to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of CH3 and the symmetric stretching vibration of =CH2, demonstrating the presence of IB molecules. After reaction for 6 min, the intensity of the typical peaks of IB at 2800–3000 cm−1 over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O catalyst was much stronger than that over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst, suggesting that Ce addition could enhance the adsorption of IB at catalyst surface as shown in Fig. 8a. Assuming the increase of IB signal (2800–3000 cm−1) and MAL signal (1700–1900 cm−1) as IB adsorption and reaction and MAL production, respectively, the kinetic behavior could be further tentatively obtained. The first-order reaction for IB and MAL on the catalyst was supposed and then the fitted curve of rate constant (k = −1/t ln(i/i0)) was gained, where i represents the intensity of absorption band, t stands for the reaction time. However, the down-bent curve over the two catalysts was obtained as shown in Fig. S4. The Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst had the lower kIB value of 0.96 min−1 than that (1.73 min−1) of the Ce-doped catalyst in the initial 6 min suggested that Ce addition was beneficial to the adsorption of IB molecules on the catalyst. Meanwhile, kMAL value of 0.91 min−1 over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst was decreased compared to that (1.81 min−1) of the Ce-doped catalyst in the initial 6 min indicated that Ce addition was beneficial to the generation of MAL molecules on the catalyst and improved reaction rate. In addition, as described in Fig. 8b,c, the intensity of all the typical peaks of reactant IB and products reached the maximum (steady-state) after 22 min over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst. However, the time to steady-state was 16 min toward the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O catalyst. This suggested that the addition of Ce promoted the IB adsorption and oxidation, meanwhile, enhanced generation of MAL as well as the reaction rate. These advancements were attributed to the enhancement of mobility ability, the variation of active oxygen species content and the adjustment of the Olattice/Odefect ratio. Moreover, the presence of MAL and COx products implied that IB could react with the active surface oxygen species on the catalyst in the absence of gas oxygen, consistent with the results of i-C4-TPD. By comparison with the in-situ FTIR signal of the products over the two catalysts with or without Ce doping after reaction for 6 min as shown in Fig. 8a, there was no peak appeared at 1700–1900 cm−1 corresponded to MAL on the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst. Meanwhile, a tiny peak at 2362 and 2339 cm−1 assigned to the presence of a small amount of COx was observed on the catalyst. This suggested that IB was firstly converted to COx over the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst. For Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O sample after reaction for 6 min, strong signals were detected at 1700–1900 and 1600–1680 cm−1, with no peak attributed to COx, supporting that IB had already transformed to MAL and aromatic by-products, hampering the generation of COx after Ce doping. 3.7 The proposed mechanism of CE over the IB selective oxidation According to the results of the composition, structure and reaction evaluation of the catalysts, the effect of Ce over the performance of the Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalysts had been proposed, as presented in Scheme 1 . In general, Ce addition promotes the generation of defects and the Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox couples, meanwhile, weakens metal-oxygen bond in the catalysts, produces the phase-synergistic interaction between Ce and Co species, thus regulates the catalytic redox ability, oxygen storage capacity, oxygen mobility, basicity, adsorption and activation ability for substrate molecules as well as catalytic performance of the catalyst in the reaction of IB selective oxidation to MAL. The role of Ce is specifically described in the following two aspects. On one hand, the addition of Ce enhances the generation of defects and changed the redox property of the catalyst, thus greatly improves the oxygen storage and oxygen migration capacity of the catalyst, as found by the characterizations of XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD-CO, XPS, O2-TPD and EPR. Meanwhile, the molar ratio of the lattice oxygen and defect oxygen species on the catalyst surface could be adjusted by adding appropriate amount of Ce to the catalyst. Both the surface defect oxygen and lattice oxygen species of the catalysts are proposed to be very important active sites for the reaction. Moreover, the molar ratio of the two above-mentioned active species was very beneficial for the IB adsorption and activation, as observed in the measurement of i-C4-TPD and in-situ IB-FTIR spectra, thus Ce addition significantly improved MAL selectivity and inhibited COx selectivity. On the other hand, the formation of redox pairs caused by the addition of Ce can also improve the medium-strong basicity of the catalyst, as detected by CO2-TPD, facilitate the electron-rich MAL desorption from the catalyst and improve the selectivity of MAL in the reaction. 4 Conclusion In summary, the series of Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5CexK0.5O catalysts with different Ce doping contents were prepared by facile co-precipitation method and investigated in-depth for the reaction of selective oxidation of IB to MAL. The Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5Ce0.2K0.5O catalyst showed the IB conversion of 93.5% with MAL selectivity of 70.6%, which was significantly improved by comparison with that of the Mo12Bi1.5Fe1.5Co5K0.5O catalyst (IB conversion: 98.9%, MAL selectivity: 47.9%). Combination with the structure characterization and catalytic performance, the dramatically enhanced MAL selectivity was mainly attributed to that the induction of Ce could produce the defects and the interaction between Ce and Co, bring the Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox pairs, thus regulate the active defect oxygen and lattice oxygen species on the catalyst surface to the proper molar ratio which was the pivotal factor for accelerating the catalytic performance. In addition, the adsorption and activation of IB molecules as well as desorption of MAL from the catalyst were enhanced with the Ce addition, which also contributed to the prompting the catalytic activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the mechanism of multi-component metal oxide catalyst for the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein has long been challenging for its complexity. Herein, the key role of Ce on the Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalysts for accelerating the selectivity of methacrolein was revealed. It was suggested that the Ce addition could replace the Bi3+ and then generate defects which changed the transformation of electron and the migration mobility of ions: Ⅰ. the production of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox couples regulated the catalytic redox ability; and Ⅱ. the interaction effect between Ce and Co enhanced the storage capacity and mobility of oxygen which could benefit the adsorption and activation ability for isobutene molecules. Interestingly, it was found that adding appropriate amount of Ce adjusted the molar ratio of the catalytically active lattice oxygen and defect oxygen species. Therefore, proper amount of Ce addition to the catalyst significantly accelerated the methacrolein selectivity from 47.9% to 70.6%.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein over Ce-accelerated Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalyst
